documents.content: The Aurora kinases are a family of serine/threonine kinases crucial for regulating mitosis. Overexpression of the Aurora kinases has been reported in multiple cancer types. They play important roles in driving an oncogenic transformation of cancer cells by regulating their survival and

metadata.title: Aurora kinases, emerging critical targets for cancer treatment and related new therapeutic strategies.

documents.content: oncogenic transformation of cancer cells by regulating their survival and proliferation, mainly because of the kinases' mitotic activity. Aurora kinase inhibitors (AKIs) were developed and tested in clinical trials and effectively suppressed many cancer types, suggesting the potential for Aurora

metadata.title: Aurora kinases, emerging critical targets for cancer treatment and related new therapeutic strategies.
metadata.authors: Chung S; Sperier E; Graciano K; Hu X; Guo H; Xu J

documents.content: suppressed many cancer types, suggesting the potential for Aurora kinases as a novel therapeutic target. Aurora kinase inhibition has also been well-documented to enhance chemotherapy effectiveness in various cancers. However, not all cancer types respond to AKIs, and the mechanisms behind the

metadata.title: Aurora kinases, emerging critical targets for cancer treatment and related new therapeutic strategies.
metadata.authors: Chung S; Sperier E; Graciano K; Hu X; Guo H; Xu J

documents.content: not all cancer types respond to AKIs, and the mechanisms behind the resistance are still elusive. metadata.title: Aurora kinases, emerging critical targets for cancer treatment and related new therapeutic strategies.

metadata.title: Aurora kinases, emerging critical targets for cancer treatment and related new therapeutic strategies.

documents.content: Plants and animals/humans have evolved sophisticated innate immune systems to cope with microbial attack. Innate immunity implies the presence of membrane-located and intracellular receptors to recognize compounds released by damage or by invading pathogens. After detection the receptor molecules

metadata.title: Redox-signaling in innate immune memory: Similar mechanisms in animals/humans and plants.
metadata.authors: Lindermayr C; Yildirim AÖ

documents.content: by damage or by invading pathogens. After detection the receptor molecules initiate intracellular defense signaling, resulting in cell death and/or production of defense molecules. Interestingly, the defense response includes also memory mechanisms, which allow the organisms to better cope with

metadata.title: Redox-signaling in innate immune memory: Similar mechanisms in animals/humans and plants.
metadata.authors: Lindermayr C; Yildirim AÖ

documents.content: also memory mechanisms, which allow the organisms to better cope with future microbial attacks. Redox mechanisms play an important role in defense signaling. In this review article, we compare the innate immune memory of animals/humans and plants and describe how reversible nitric oxide- and

metadata.title: Redox-signaling in innate immune memory: Similar mechanisms in animals/humans and plants.
metadata.authors: Lindermayr C; Yildirim AÖ

documents.content: of animals/humans and plants and describe how reversible nitric oxide- and reactive oxygen species-dependent protein modifications enable the activation of defense signaling proteins and transcription factors and regulate the activity of chromatin modifying enzymes to establish innate immune

metadata.title: Redox-signaling in innate immune memory: Similar mechanisms in animals/humans and plants.
metadata.authors: Lindermayr C; Yildirim AÖ

documents.content: the activity of chromatin modifying enzymes to establish innate immune memory. We hope to encourage efforts to characterize further molecular redox mechanisms of the innate immune memory, which might enable the development of new immunotherapies.

documents.content: Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is a significant global source of morbidity and mortality, with a frequently grim prognosis. Microvascular dysfunction in the form of small vessel disease appears to cause the vast majority of spontaneous cerebral hemorrhages. Cerebral microbleeds, hemorrhagic markers

metadata.title: Cerebral microbleeds and renal dysfunction: Degenerative neurobiological shared mechanisms within intracerebral hemorrhage.
metadata.authors: Enache II; Manea MM; Tuță S; Sîrbu CA

documents.content: cerebral hemorrhages. Cerebral microbleeds, hemorrhagic markers of small vessel disease, seem prevalent in ICH patients. The cerebral microvasculature resembles the renal microvasculature and therefore, the two may share common, complex degenerative mechanisms of frailty, and renal impairment

metadata.title: Cerebral microbleeds and renal dysfunction: Degenerative neurobiological shared mechanisms within intracerebral hemorrhage.
metadata.authors: Enache II; Manea MM; Tuță S; Sîrbu CA

documents.content: common, complex degenerative mechanisms of frailty, and renal impairment appears to be an additional burden on ICH cases. There could be a potential neurobiological interplay between cerebral microbleeds and renal dysfunction in the context of ICH, with possible bidirectional influences on a

metadata.title: Cerebral microbleeds and renal dysfunction: Degenerative neurobiological shared mechanisms within intracerebral hemorrhage.
metadata.authors: Enache II; Manea MM; Tuță S; Sîrbu CA

documents.content: in the context of ICH, with possible bidirectional influences on a molecular and cellular level. Separately, the two entities appear to influence ICH occurrence, recurrence and prognosis. Our review sheds light on the fact that when cerebral microbleeds and renal impairment are brought together,

metadata.title: Cerebral microbleeds and renal dysfunction: Degenerative neurobiological shared mechanisms within intracerebral hemorrhage.
metadata.authors: Enache II; Manea MM; Tuță S; Sîrbu CA

documents.content: that when cerebral microbleeds and renal impairment are brought together, there is potential for clinically relevant pathophysiological feedback mechanisms.

Quantum analogous spin state of ultrasonic guided wave is primarily manifest nonzero spin angular momentum (SAM) and its integration over the wave path gives the topological phase acquired due to the modified polarity. The topological geometric phase gives a new opportunity to

metadata.title: Quantized topological phase of ultrasonic guided wave with spin orbit interaction.
metadata.authors: Banerjee S

documents.content: polarity. The topological geometric phase gives a new opportunity to quantify damage state in materials using ultrasonic guided wave that were usually considered difficult. metadata.title: Quantized topological phase of ultrasonic guided wave with spin orbit interaction.
metadata.authors: Banerjee S

metadata.title: Quantized topological phase of ultrasonic guided wave with spin orbit interaction.

metadata.title: Quantized topological phase of ultrasonic guided wave with spin orbit interaction.

documents.content: of Noether current and three-dimensional SOI. It is shown that polarity driven manifestation of SAM can be quantified, and topological geometric phase can be calculated. metadata.title: Quantized topological phase of ultrasonic guided wave with spin orbit interaction.

documents.content: The increasing demand for point-of-care detection of low-concentration cancer biomarkers has necessitated the development of innovative nanozyme-based sensing technologies. Here, a smartphone-integrated platform is presented that utilizes artificial intelligence (AI) to detect abnormal levels of the

metadata.title: Development of AI-integrated smartphone sponge-based sensors utilizing His@Co-NC nanozymes for highly sensitive sarcosine detection.
metadata.authors: Liu P; Shi C; Liu Y; Yang F; Yang Y

documents.content: utilizes artificial intelligence (AI) to detect abnormal levels of the prostate cancer marker sarcosine (Sar) in humans. The platform comprises a histidine (His)-modified single-atom cobalt nanozyme (His@Co-NC), a white absorbent sponge for color development, and an AI-powered image acquisition

metadata.title: Development of AI-integrated smartphone sponge-based sensors utilizing His@Co-NC nanozymes for highly sensitive sarcosine detection.
metadata.authors: Liu P; Shi C; Liu Y; Yang F; Yang Y

documents.content: sponge for color development, and an AI-powered image acquisition system utilizing Monte Carlo color analysis (MC-CA). The biomimetic coordination of His with single-atom Co significantly enhances its peroxidase-like activity, rendering it 48-fold more active than natural horseradish peroxidase

metadata.title: Development of AI-integrated smartphone sponge-based sensors utilizing His@Co-NC nanozymes for highly sensitive sarcosine detection.
metadata.authors: Liu P; Shi C; Liu Y; Yang F; Yang Y

documents.content: rendering it 48-fold more active than natural horseradish peroxidase (HRP), with a Michaelis constant (Km) of 0.076 mM, much lower than the 3.7 mM observed for HRP. This enhanced activity results in the generation of more intense colorimetric signals when reacting with

metadata.title: Development of AI-integrated smartphone sponge-based sensors utilizing His@Co-NC nanozymes for highly sensitive sarcosine detection.
metadata.authors: Liu P; Shi C; Liu Y; Yang F; Yang Y

documents.content: in the generation of more intense colorimetric signals when reacting with 3,3',5,5'-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB). The AI algorithm captures over 1000 sampling RGB points on the color-revealing sponge surface, achieving a color recognition rate of over 95 % within 5 s, ensuring rapid and accurate

metadata.title: Development of AI-integrated smartphone sponge-based sensors utilizing His@Co-NC nanozymes for highly sensitive sarcosine detection.
metadata.authors: Liu P; Shi C; Liu Y; Yang F; Yang Y

documents.content: recognition rate of over 95 % within 5 s, ensuring rapid and accurate detection. The integration of nanozyme with AI-driven data acquisition addresses two critical challenges: the limited chromogenic intensity in low-centration biomarker detection and the potential subjectivity in color rendering

metadata.title: Development of AI-integrated smartphone sponge-based sensors utilizing His@Co-NC nanozymes for highly sensitive sarcosine detection.
metadata.authors: Liu P; Shi C; Liu Y; Yang F; Yang Y

documents.content: biomarker detection and the potential subjectivity in color rendering results. Immobilized on a hierarchically porous sponge, the system achieves a detection limit of 0.28 μM, with less than 5 % signal variation across 20 repeated cycles. This integration of AI and nanozyme-based detection holds

metadata.title: Development of AI-integrated smartphone sponge-based sensors utilizing His@Co-NC nanozymes for highly sensitive sarcosine detection.
metadata.authors: Liu P; Shi C; Liu Y; Yang F; Yang Y

documents.content: repeated cycles. This integration of AI and nanozyme-based detection holds significant promise for advancing biosensors that provide precise data output, offering vast potential for widespread applications in the early detection of disease biomarkers and other analytes.

metadata.title: Development of AI-integrated smartphone sponge-based sensors utilizing His@Co-NC nanozymes for highly sensitive sarcosine detection.

documents.content: Metaphors are extensively utilized by those studying and practicing medicine. Those metaphors employed in provider-patient communication in medical settings are particularly significant due to their dynamic and interactive nature, and their direct contribution to the completion of core medical tasks

metadata.title: Use of metaphor in provider-patient communication in medical settings: A systematic review.
metadata.authors: Liu X

documents.content: and their direct contribution to the completion of core medical tasks and the quality of provider-patient interaction and relationship. We aim to: (1) to identify and summarize existing literature on the use of metaphors in patient-provider communication in medical settings; (2) discuss the

metadata.title: Use of metaphor in provider-patient communication in medical settings: A systematic review.
metadata.authors: Liu X

documents.content: in patient-provider communication in medical settings; (2) discuss the implications of these studies for medical research and practice; and (3) provide recommendations for future research in this area. The Chinese National Knowledge Infrastructure and the Web of Science Core Collections were

metadata.title: Use of metaphor in provider-patient communication in medical settings: A systematic review.
metadata.authors: Liu X

documents.content: Knowledge Infrastructure and the Web of Science Core Collections were systematically searched, and the obtained literature was combined with the online resource "Metaphor in Health Discourse and Communication". The resultant literature was then screened according to preset inclusion and exclusion

metadata.title: Use of metaphor in provider-patient communication in medical settings: A systematic review.
metadata.authors: Liu X

documents.content: literature was then screened according to preset inclusion and exclusion criteria. Of 265 articles identified, 16 studies were found to completely meet our purpose and inclusion criteria. Analysis revealed 7 major themes, including the metaphor's facilitating functions, harmful effects, differences

metadata.title: Use of metaphor in provider-patient communication in medical settings: A systematic review.
metadata.authors: Liu X

documents.content: the metaphor's facilitating functions, harmful effects, differences between providers and patients etc. Metaphors were found to enhance provider-patient relationship and communication and promote shared understanding and decision-making. Metaphors play a significant role in provider-patient

metadata.title: Use of metaphor in provider-patient communication in medical settings: A systematic review.
metadata.authors: Liu X

documents.content: and decision-making. Metaphors play a significant role in provider-patient communication in medical settings, offering both benefits and challenges. Future research can further explore other aspects of metaphor use in medical settings, and update the research methodology and approaches by

metadata.title: Use of metaphor in provider-patient communication in medical settings: A systematic review.
metadata.authors: Liu X

documents.content: in medical settings, and update the research methodology and approaches by collecting larger, balanced samples of metaphor, conducting quantitative analyses of metaphor efficacy, and doing multimodal analysis of metaphor use.

documents.content: Phalloplasty has become an increasingly prevalent component of gender affirming surgery in recent years. While it is most commonly performed using a radial forearm free flap (RFFF) due to the thin and pliable nature of this tissue, the large surface area of tissue traditionally required to create a

metadata.title: The novel use of virtual surgical planning in radial forearm phalloplasty.

documents.content: the large surface area of tissue traditionally required to create a phallus often incurs a tremendous donor site morbidity. The dimensions of the flap size needed have been traditionally estimated by the surgeon at the beginning of the case, but can be inaccurate as they do not take into account

metadata.title: The novel use of virtual surgical planning in radial forearm phalloplasty.
metadata.authors: Margulies IG; Lava CX; Singh A; Li K; Del Corral GA
metadata.journal: Journal of plastic, reconstructive & aesthetic surgery : JPRAS

documents.content: of the case, but can be inaccurate as they do not take into account the soft tissue thickness as it relates to the girth of the arm. Thus, there can be a tendency to overestimate or underestimate the amount of tissue needed, thus increasing the donor and flap morbidity. In order to improve the

metadata.title: The novel use of virtual surgical planning in radial forearm phalloplasty.
metadata.authors: Margulies IG; Lava CX; Singh A; Li K; Del Corral GA
metadata.journal: Journal of plastic, reconstructive & aesthetic surgery : JPRAS

documents.content: thus increasing the donor and flap morbidity. In order to improve the accuracy of these dimensions and facilitate the minimization of tissue harvest as well as improve operative efficiency, we propose the first use of virtual surgical planning (VSP) in RFFF phalloplasty, and we describe its use in

metadata.title: The novel use of virtual surgical planning in radial forearm phalloplasty.

metadata.journal: Journal of plastic, reconstructive & aesthetic surgery : JPRAS

documents.content: surgical planning (VSP) in RFFF phalloplasty, and we describe its use in this case series. Using CT-guided analysis that takes into account extremity girth and three-dimensional soft tissue measurements, a precise and sterilizable template is created for use in surgical planning. This novel

metadata.title: The novel use of virtual surgical planning in radial forearm phalloplasty.
metadata.authors: Margulies IG; Lava CX; Singh A; Li K; Del Corral GA
metadata.journal: Journal of plastic, reconstructive & aesthetic surgery : JPRAS

documents.content: sterilizable template is created for use in surgical planning. This novel application of VSP in RFFF phalloplasty has the potential to both decrease operative time and donor site morbidity.

documents.content: Post-acute sequelae of COVID-19 (PASC), characterized by persistent symptoms like fatigue, cognitive impairments, and mental health problems, requires effective coping strategies for symptom management, yet their impact on health outcomes in PASC patients remains unclear. This study examines differences in coping strategies across subgroups, changes over time, and their relationship with PASC symptoms and physical and mental health. In a prospective study, conducted at the Post-COVID Center of the University

metadata.title: Coping competence and health outcomes in post-COVID: A prospective study on the role of adaptive strategies in symptom management and physical and mental health.
metadata.authors: Koller K; Herold R; Morawa E; Erim Y

documents.content: a prospective study, conducted at the Post-COVID Center of the University Hospital of Erlangen, patients were assessed at baseline (T0) and follow-up (T1; M = 4.46 months, SD = 2.27). PASC symptom severity (PCS score), fatigue (FSS), post-exertional malaise (DSQ-PEM), and depressive symptoms (PHQ-9) were also assessed.

Women scored

documents.content: observed in the other factors and overall patient competence. Women scored higher than men in religious/spiritual coping, coping competence, and healthy lifestyle (all p < .001). documents.content: Segmentation of 3D medical images, and brain segmentation in particular, is an important topic in neuroimaging and in radiotherapy. Overcoming the current, time consuming, practise of manual delineation of brain tumours and providing an accurate, explainable, and replicable method of segmentation of

metadata.title: Symbolic and hybrid AI for brain tissue segmentation using spatial model checking.
metadata.authors: Belmonte G; Ciancia V; Massink M

documents.content: an accurate, explainable, and replicable method of segmentation of the tumour area and related tissues is therefore an open research challenge. In this paper, we first propose a novel symbolic approach to brain segmentation and delineation of brain lesions based on spatial model checking. This

metadata.title: Symbolic and hybrid AI for brain tissue segmentation using spatial model checking.
metadata.authors: Belmonte G; Ciancia V; Massink M

documents.content: and delineation of brain lesions based on spatial model checking. This method has its foundations in the theory of closure spaces, a generalisation of topological spaces, and spatial logics. At its core is a high-level declarative logic language for image analysis, ImgQL, and an efficient spatial

metadata.title: Symbolic and hybrid AI for brain tissue segmentation using spatial model checking.
metadata.authors: Belmonte G; Ciancia V; Massink M

documents.content: logic language for image analysis, ImgQL, and an efficient spatial model checker, VoxLogicA, exploiting state-of-the-art image analysis libraries in its model checking algorithm. We then illustrate how this technique can be combined with Machine Learning techniques leading to a hybrid AI approach

metadata.title: Symbolic and hybrid AI for brain tissue segmentation using spatial model checking.
metadata.authors: Belmonte G; Ciancia V; Massink M

documents.content: combined with Machine Learning techniques leading to a hybrid AI approach that provides accurate and explainable segmentation results. We show the results of the application of the symbolic approach on several public datasets with 3D magnetic resonance (MR) images. Three datasets are provided by

metadata.title: Symbolic and hybrid AI for brain tissue segmentation using spatial model checking.
metadata.authors: Belmonte G; Ciancia V; Massink M

documents.content: with 3D magnetic resonance (MR) images. Three datasets are provided by the 2017, 2019 and 2020 international MICCAI BraTS Challenges with 210, 259 and 293 MR images, respectively, and the fourth is the BrainWeb dataset with 20 (synthetic) 3D patient images of the normal brain. We then apply the

metadata.title: Symbolic and hybrid AI for brain tissue segmentation using spatial model checking.
metadata.authors: Belmonte G; Ciancia V; Massink M

documents.content: 20 (synthetic) 3D patient images of the normal brain. We then apply the hybrid AI method to the BraTS 2020 training set. Our segmentation results are shown to be in line with the state-of-the-art with respect to other recent approaches, both from the accuracy point of view as well as from the view

metadata.title: Symbolic and hybrid AI for brain tissue segmentation using spatial model checking.
metadata.authors: Belmonte G; Ciancia V; Massink M

documents.content: approaches, both from the accuracy point of view as well as from the view of computational efficiency, but with the advantage of them being explainable.

metadata.title: Symbolic and hybrid AI for brain tissue segmentation using spatial model checking.
metadata.authors: Belmonte G; Ciancia V; Massink M

documents.content: The association of a given human phenotype with a genetic variant remains a critical challenge in biomedical research. metadata.authors: Mellina Andreu JL; Bernal L; Skarmeta AF; Ryten M; Álvarez S; García AC; Botía JA

documents.content: phenotype attributes, while maintaining explainability through Integrated Gradients. PhenoLinker consistently outperforms existing models in both retrospective and temporal validation tasks. This system can aid in the discovery of new associations and in understanding the consequences of human

documents.content: With the rapid development and progress of big data and artificial intelligence technology, the ICD coding problem of electronic medical records has been effectively solved. The deep learning method, which replaces the manual coding method, has improved the quality and efficiency of coding. However,

metadata.title: ICD code mapping model based on clinical text tree structure.
metadata.authors: Xue J; Lu P

documents.content: coding method, has improved the quality and efficiency of coding. However, it also faces some challenges, such as poor and fuzzy semantic representation of clinical record text and failure to consider the structural characteristics of clinical records. To address these problems, our study proposed

metadata.title: ICD code mapping model based on clinical text tree structure.
metadata.authors: Xue J; Lu P

documents.content: of clinical records. To address these problems, our study proposed an ICD Coding model (TRansformer and TRee-lstm for ICD Coding, TRIC), which enables adequate automatic ICD encoding of unstructured clinical records. In this model, the structure and features of clinical records are extracted by the

metadata.title: ICD code mapping model based on clinical text tree structure.
metadata.authors: Xue J; Lu P

documents.content: model, the structure and features of clinical records are extracted by the constituency tree model and the transformer based model respectively, and the Tree-lstm model is used to enrich the features. Then bioBERT pre-training model is used to highlight the role of key ICD coding and improve its

metadata.title: ICD code mapping model based on clinical text tree structure.
metadata.authors: Xue J; Lu P

documents.content: model is used to highlight the role of key ICD coding and improve its matching performance. Finally, it is classified by a fully connected neural network classifier to realize the many-to-many mapping between clinical records and ICD codes. On the widely used MIMIC-III full data set and sample data

metadata.title: ICD code mapping model based on clinical text tree structure.
metadata.authors: Xue J; Lu P

documents.content: and ICD codes. On the widely used MIMIC-III full data set and sample data set, the TRIC model is compared with 12 benchmark models. The best results of 0.586, 0.109, 0.989, 0.937 and 0.758 were obtained for MiF, MaF, MiAUC, MaAUC and P@8, respectively, which verified that the TRIC model can

metadata.title: ICD code mapping model based on clinical text tree structure.
metadata.authors: Xue J; Lu P

documents.content: MiAUC, MaAUC and P@8, respectively, which verified that the TRIC model can effectively improve the quality of ICD automatic coding.

documents.content: Low-grade gliomas (LGGs) are among the most problematic brain tumors to reliably segment in FLAIR MRI, and effective delineation of these lesions is critical for clinical diagnosis, treatment planning, and patient monitoring. Nevertheless, conventional U-Net-based approaches usually suffer from the

metadata.title: A combined attention mechanism for brain tumor segmentation of lower-grade glioma in magnetic resonance images.
metadata.authors: Hedibi H; Beladgham M; Bouida A

documents.content: Nevertheless, conventional U-Net-based approaches usually suffer from the loss of critical structural details owing to repetitive down-sampling, while the encoder features often retain irrelevant information that is not properly utilized by the decoder. To solve these challenges, this paper offers

metadata.title: A combined attention mechanism for brain tumor segmentation of lower-grade glioma in magnetic resonance images.
metadata.authors: Hedibi H; Beladgham M; Bouida A

documents.content: utilized by the decoder. To solve these challenges, this paper offers a dual-attention U-shaped design, named ECASE-Unet, which seamlessly integrates Efficient Channel Attention (ECA) and Squeeze-and-Excitation (SE) blocks in both the encoder and decoder stages. By selectively recalibrating

metadata.title: A combined attention mechanism for brain tumor segmentation of lower-grade glioma in magnetic resonance images.
metadata.authors: Hedibi H; Beladgham M; Bouida A

documents.content: in both the encoder and decoder stages. By selectively recalibrating channel-wise information, the model increases diagnostically significant regions of interest and reduces noise. Furthermore, dilated convolutions are introduced at the bottleneck layer to capture multi-scale contextual cues

metadata.title: A combined attention mechanism for brain tumor segmentation of lower-grade glioma in magnetic resonance images.
metadata.authors: Hedibi H; Beladgham M; Bouida A

documents.content: introduced at the bottleneck layer to capture multi-scale contextual cues without inflating computational complexity, and dropout regularization is systematically applied to prevent overfitting on heterogeneous data. Experimental results on the Kaggle Low-Grade-Glioma dataset suggest that

metadata.title: A combined attention mechanism for brain tumor segmentation of lower-grade glioma in magnetic resonance images.
metadata.authors: Hedibi H; Beladgham M; Bouida A

documents.content: Experimental results on the Kaggle Low-Grade-Glioma dataset suggest that ECASE-Unet greatly outperforms previous segmentation algorithms, reaching a Dice coefficient of 0.9197 and an Intersection over Union (IoU) of 0.8521. Comprehensive ablation studies further reveal that integrating ECA and SE

metadata.title: A combined attention mechanism for brain tumor segmentation of lower-grade glioma in magnetic resonance images.
metadata.authors: Hedibi H; Beladgham M; Bouida A

documents.content: Comprehensive ablation studies further reveal that integrating ECA and SE modules delivers complementing benefits, supporting the model's robust efficacy in precisely identifying LGG boundaries. These findings underline the potential of ECASE-Unet to expedite clinical operations and improve patient

metadata.title: A combined attention mechanism for brain tumor segmentation of lower-grade glioma in magnetic resonance images.
metadata.authors: Hedibi H; Beladgham M; Bouida A

documents.content: of ECASE-Unet to expedite clinical operations and improve patient outcomes. Future work will focus on improving the model's applicability to new MRI modalities and studying the integration of clinical characteristics for a more comprehensive characterization of brain tumors.

documents.content: Phalaenopsis orchids are important ornamental plants with considerable economic value. The blooming of plants is affected by numerous internal and external factors and is regulated

metadata.title: Identification and functional analysis of J-domain proteins involved in determining flowering time in Phalaenopsis orchids.
metadata.authors: Jiang L; Ren Y; Luo H; Liu H; Wu J; Hu S; Jiang Y; Wang G

metadata.title: Identification and functional analysis of J-domain proteins involved in determining flowering time in Phalaenopsis orchids.

documents.content: during flowering. The maximum expression level of PhJ3a was observed in the shoot apical meristem, whereas the peak expression of PhJ3b was detected in the inflorescence meristem. Low-temperature and hormone treatments significantly affected the transcript levels of PhJ3a and PhJ3b. Overexpression

metadata.title: Identification and functional analysis of J-domain proteins involved in determining flowering time in Phalaenopsis orchids.

Overexpression of the two PhJ3 genes in Arabidopsis resulted in significantly earlier bolting in the transgenic plants than in the wild-type plants. Additionally, transient overexpression of PhJ3a and PhJ3b in Phalaenopsis promoted the expression

documents.content: The rapid advancements of artificial intelligence (AI) in healthcare have triggered a significant literacy gap among nursing professionals, raising concerns about implementation, ethical use, and impact on practice. This article introduces the AI-ABCs framework as a structured approach to building

metadata.title: Artificial intelligence 101: Building literacy with the AI-ABCs framework.
metadata.authors: Kobeissi MM; Santa Maria DM; Park JI

documents.content: introduces the AI-ABCs framework as a structured approach to building foundational AI literacy among nurse leaders, educators, and healthcare professionals. The framework was developed through a comprehensive literature synthesis and expert consultation in nursing informatics to identify essential

metadata.title: Artificial intelligence 101: Building literacy with the AI-ABCs framework.
metadata.authors: Kobeissi MM; Santa Maria DM; Park JI

documents.content: and expert consultation in nursing informatics to identify essential components of AI literacy for healthcare professionals. The AI-ABCs framework provides an accessible entry point for AI literacy through three components: A-AI-Basics, B-Benefits and Challenges of AI, and C-Core Components and

metadata.title: Artificial intelligence 101: Building literacy with the AI-ABCs framework.
metadata.authors: Kobeissi MM; Santa Maria DM; Park JI

documents.content: A-AI-Basics, B-Benefits and Challenges of AI, and C-Core Components and Terminologies in AI. The AI-ABCs framework offers nurse leaders and educators a structured approach to developing foundational AI literacy necessary for guiding policy development, curriculum integration, and ethical

metadata.title: Artificial intelligence 101: Building literacy with the AI-ABCs framework.
metadata.authors: Kobeissi MM; Santa Maria DM; Park JI

documents.content: for guiding policy development, curriculum integration, and ethical implementation in healthcare and educational settings, aligning with recommendations from key professional organizations.

metadata.authors: Kobeissi MM; Santa Maria DM; Park JI

documents.content: Assessing long-term trends in zooplankton community structure is essential for the monitoring of aquatic systems. documents.content: Contamination by organic pollutants, even in remote regions, poses a growing threat to wildlife, including seabirds. However, for many seabirds breeding at high latitudes, both the extent and nature of contaminant exposure remain largely unknown. This study aimed to identify the persistent organic

metadata.title: Anthropogenic compounds in the northernmost Atlantic puffin population.
metadata.authors: Underwood AKP; Descamps S; Sagerup K; Herzke D; Gabrielsen GW

This study aimed to identify the persistent organic pollutants (POPs) present in the Svalbard Atlantic puffin Fratercula arctica at the northern limit of its range. We also compare contaminant concentrations with those found in other species breeding on Svalbard and in puffin

metadata.title: Anthropogenic compounds in the northernmost Atlantic puffin population.
metadata.authors: Underwood AKP; Descamps S; Sagerup K; Herzke D; Gabrielsen GW

documents.content: with those found in other species breeding on Svalbard and in puffin colonies further south. The Svalbard puffins were found to be contaminated by organochlorine pesticides (OCPs), polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), and per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS). No significant sex difference was

metadata.title: Anthropogenic compounds in the northernmost Atlantic puffin population.
metadata.authors: Underwood AKP; Descamps S; Sagerup K; Herzke D; Gabrielsen GW

documents.content: and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS). No significant sex difference was found. OCPs, PCBs and/or PFASs concentrations in Svalbard puffins were comparable to those of Brünnich's guillemots Uria lomvia, black guillemots Cepphus grylle, and/or little auks Alle alle, but lower than in glaucous gulls

OCP and PCB concentrations were lower on Svalbard than in puffin colonies further south. This study is the first to

metadata.title: Anthropogenic compounds in the northernmost Atlantic puffin population.

documents.content: Svalbard than in puffin colonies further south. This study is the first to document PFAS concentrations in puffins, therefore it remains unknown whether PFAS levels were also lower on Svalbard than further south. documents.content: This study investigates the effects of Stokes drift, wind drift factor and angle on oil transport using the MEDSLIK-II model, focusing on the 2019 P-53 platform spill in Brazilian waters. Model accuracy was assessed by the difference in distances between simulated and observed trajectories from

metadata.title: The effect of wind parametrizations in MEDSLIK-II oil spill simulations: A case study of the FPU P-53 incident in Brazilian waters.
metadata.authors: Correia Lima EJA; Queiroz S; Ishimaru MEA; Kusuky ME; Moura MDC; Araujo M; Mendonca LFF; Lentini CAD; da Cunha Lima AT

documents.content: difference in distances between simulated and observed trajectories from Synthetic Aperture Radar. Sixteen simulations tested different wind drift angles (10°-45°), drift factors (0 %, 3 % and 6 %), and Stokes drift inclusion. A 6 % drift factor accelerated coastward transport, while angles >25°

metadata.title: The effect of wind parametrizations in MEDSLIK-II oil spill simulations: A case study of the FPU P-53 incident in Brazilian waters.
metadata.authors: Correia Lima EJA; Queiroz S; Ishimaru MEA; Kusuky ME; Moura MDC; Araujo M; Mendonca LFF; Lentini CAD; da Cunha Lima AT

documents.content: A 6 % drift factor accelerated coastward transport, while angles >25° reduced discrepancies between simulated and observed slick trajectories. The best parameterization combined a 45° angle with a 6 % factor (distance errors: 23.49-21.16 km), correctly simulating the coastal impact region. Contrary

metadata.title: The effect of wind parametrizations in MEDSLIK-II oil spill simulations: A case study of the FPU P-53 incident in Brazilian waters.
metadata.authors: Correia Lima EJA; Queiroz S; Ishimaru MEA; Kusuky ME; Moura MDC; Araujo M; Mendonca LFF; Lentini CAD; da Cunha Lima AT

documents.content: 23.49-21.16 km), correctly simulating the coastal impact region. Contrary to previous studies, Stokes drift slightly worsened model performance. This effect and the high distance errors were likely due to (1) inconsistencies in the wind direction data used in the model and actual conditions during

metadata.title: The effect of wind parametrizations in MEDSLIK-II oil spill simulations: A case study of the FPU P-53 incident in Brazilian waters.

documents.content: Historically, global mental health has struggled between an evidence based biomedical model and a rights-based approach focusing on user perspectives. A particularly problematic global mental health challenge is the use of restraints in psychiatry, highly regulated but controversial and risky, often

metadata.title: RIGHTCARE-PR: Reporting guidelines for human rights in child and adolescent psychiatry.
metadata.authors: Pértega E; Holmberg C
metadata.journal: International journal of law and psychiatry

documents.content: in psychiatry, highly regulated but controversial and risky, often deemed incompatible with human rights. Despite calls for an absolute ban, inconsistent terms, definitions, and reporting requirements complicate an accurate understanding. Effective research reporting in light of human rights is

metadata.title: RIGHTCARE-PR: Reporting guidelines for human rights in child and adolescent psychiatry.
metadata.authors: Pértega E; Holmberg C
metadata.journal: International journal of law and psychiatry

documents.content: understanding. Effective research reporting in light of human rights is crucial for knowledge dissemination and ethical integrity. metadata.journal: International journal of law and psychiatry

documents.content: psychiatric care, integrating scientific evidence and human rights to enhance mental health service quality. documents.content: settings that found a lack of human rights considerations in scientific literature in four domains: study context, stakeholders, restraint phenomena, and regulations. metadata.title: RIGHTCARE-PR: Reporting guidelines for human rights in child and adolescent psychiatry.

metadata.journal: International journal of law and psychiatry

documents.content: a Delphi process involving international experts from law, psychiatry, and social sciences, providing a comparative perspective on legal and psychiatric practices to refine the guidelines. metadata.title: RIGHTCARE-PR: Reporting guidelines for human rights in child and adolescent psychiatry.

documents.content: interventions align with human rights principles, this paper proposes reporting standards that integrate human rights into research on child psychiatric care restraints. documents.content: For a long time, the standard chemotherapy for small cell lung cancer (SCLC) was a combination of platinum plus etoposide. In 2019, anti-PD-L1 antibodies atezolizumab or durvalumab were introduced for the treatment of extensive-stage (ES) SCLC in combination with chemotherapy. Two randomized phase

metadata.title: Treatment of small cell lung cancer; advances and future prospects.
metadata.authors: Niho S

documents.content: (ES) SCLC in combination with chemotherapy. Two randomized phase III studies (IMpower 133 and CASPIAN) demonstrated that addition of atezolizumab or durvalumab to platinum plus etoposide prolonged the overall survival in ES-SCLC patients. In addition, consolidation therapy with durvalumab after

metadata.title: Treatment of small cell lung cancer; advances and future prospects.
metadata.authors: Niho S

documents.content: ES-SCLC patients. In addition, consolidation therapy with durvalumab after chemoradiotherapy was also shown to prolong the overall survival in patients with limited-stage SCLC. Tarlatamab is a bispecific antibody that targets DLL3 and CD3. It binds to both DLL3 on cancer cells and CD3 on T cells,

metadata.title: Treatment of small cell lung cancer; advances and future prospects.

documents.content: DLL3 and CD3. It binds to both DLL3 on cancer cells and CD3 on T cells, causing T-cell-mediated lysis of cancer cells. A phase II study (DeLLphi-301) showed a 40 % response rate and median progression-free survival of 4.9 months following tarlatamab administration in previously treated SCLC

metadata.title: Treatment of small cell lung cancer; advances and future prospects.

documents.content: 4.9 months following tarlatamab administration in previously treated SCLC patients, which led to approval of this drug in Japan for the treatment of SCLC at the end of 2024. documents.content: Temozolomide, a small-molecule drug, is primarily used to treat glioblastoma, a tumor that attacks both the spinal cord and brain. documents.content: the atomic level can help elucidate its ability to permeate through cell membranes. In this study, we constructed a simplified brain plasma membrane model to explore the microscopic structure and dynamics of Temozolomide using all-atom microsecond-scale molecular dynamics simulations. Temozolomide

metadata.title: Influence of local ordering in the permeation of Temozolomide through the brain plasmatic membrane.

documents.content: all-atom microsecond-scale molecular dynamics simulations. metadata.title: Influence of local ordering in the permeation of Temozolomide through the brain plasmatic membrane.
metadata.authors: Ge Y; Lu H; Martí J

documents.content: to lipids of the choline and cerebroside classes. To investigate the free energy barriers of Temozolomide related to its crossing of brain-like plasma membranes, we employed adaptive biasing force methods. These simulations revealed that the free energy barriers ranged between 28 and 50 kcal/mol at

metadata.title: Influence of local ordering in the permeation of Temozolomide through the brain plasmatic membrane.

documents.content: that the free energy barriers ranged between 28 and 50 kcal/mol at temperatures between 310 K and 323 K. documents.content: but that rising the temperature significantly increases the probability of barrier crossing. This is primarily due to the crucial role played by cholesterol and lipids of the cerebroside class.
